articles.headline: Homeland Security Goes Abroad. Not Everyone Is Grateful.
articles.snippet: Set up to defend the United States, the Homeland Security Department is going beyond American borders to fight foreign threats from abroad.
articles.abstract: Set up to defend the United States, the Homeland Security Department is going beyond American borders to fight foreign threats from abroad.
articles.lead_paragraph: ABOARD A P-3 ORION, over the Pacific Ocean — The Department of Homeland Security is increasingly going global.

articles.headline: How Big Tech Is Going After Your Health Care
articles.snippet: Apple, Google, Microsoft and other giants are accelerating their efforts to remake health care with new tracking apps, sensors and other tools.
articles.abstract: Apple, Google, Microsoft and other giants are accelerating their efforts to remake health care with new tracking apps, sensors and other tools.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Daniel Poston, a second-year medical student in Manhattan, opened the App Store on his iPhone a couple of weeks ago, he was astonished to see an app for a new heart study prominently featured.

articles.headline: Freed From the iPhone, the Apple Watch Finds a Medical Purpose
articles.snippet: A wave of new medical accessories are connecting to the Apple Watch so that people can manage their health from their wrist. It’s a leap forward in the utility of wearable devices.
articles.abstract: A wave of new medical accessories are connecting to the Apple Watch so that people can manage their health from their wrist. It’s a leap forward in the utility of wearable devices.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — In the last months of Steve Jobs’s life, the Apple co-founder fought cancer while managing diabetes.

articles.headline: Years of Attack Leave Obamacare a More Government-Focused Health Law
articles.snippet: Efforts by Republicans to chip away at the Affordable Care Act, culminating in the repeal of the individual mandate, have left behind a more government-focused health program.
articles.abstract: Efforts by Republicans to chip away at the Affordable Care Act, culminating in the repeal of the individual mandate, have left behind a more government-focused health program.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Affordable Care Act was conceived as a mix of publicly funded health care and privately purchased insurance, but Republican attacks, culminating this month in the death of a mandate that most Americans have insurance, are shifting the balance, giving the government a larger role than Democrats ever anticipated.

articles.headline: Unions Are Gaining a Foothold at Digital Media Companies
articles.snippet: A doubter at Vox Media, where one of the latest organizing efforts has begun, became a believer — no thanks to Twitter, he said.
articles.abstract: A doubter at Vox Media, where one of the latest organizing efforts has begun, became a believer — no thanks to Twitter, he said.
articles.lead_paragraph: After employees at the online media company Vox Media announced plans to form a union last month, German Lopez, a senior reporter at the company’s general news website Vox.com, posted a thread on Twitter that inspired a heated debate more than 1,000 comments in length.

articles.headline: Putin May Be Re-Election Shoo-in, but He’s Taking No Chances
articles.snippet: First Aleksei A. Navalny, an anticorruption activist, was blocked from running for president. Then he was warned not to organize a boycott of the election.
articles.abstract: First Aleksei A. Navalny, an anticorruption activist, was blocked from running for president. Then he was warned not to organize a boycott of the election.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Aleksei A. Navalny, a Russian anticorruption activist, would have no real chance of defeating President Vladimir V. Putin in an election. The authorities have cast him as an utterly irrelevant showboat.

articles.headline: ‘Nobody Thought It Would Come to This’: Drug Maker Teva Faces a Crisis
articles.snippet: The move by Israel’s corporate version of a celebrity to lay off 14,000 workers was greeted with outrage and a nationwide strike.
articles.abstract: The move by Israel’s corporate version of a celebrity to lay off 14,000 workers was greeted with outrage and a nationwide strike.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — To the rest of the world, Teva Pharmaceutical Industries is simply one of the world’s biggest makers of generic drugs. In Israel, it is the corporate version of a national celebrity.
articles.byline: By David Segal and Isabel Kershner

articles.headline: When Picking Apples on a Farm With 5,000 Rules, Watch Out for the Ladders
articles.snippet: Produce growers represent a textbook example of what businesses describe as regulatory fatigue. President Trump is tapping into the discontent.
articles.abstract: Produce growers represent a textbook example of what businesses describe as regulatory fatigue. President Trump is tapping into the discontent.
articles.lead_paragraph: ALTAMONT, N.Y. — For eight weeks every fall, Indian Ladder Farms, a fifth-generation family operation near Albany, kicks into peak season.

articles.headline: Geely Buys Stake in Volvo Trucks, Despite China Restrictions
articles.snippet: The government in Beijing has unveiled an array of new regulations to temper outbound investment. But Chinese companies are still going global.
articles.abstract: The government in Beijing has unveiled an array of new regulations to temper outbound investment. But Chinese companies are still going global.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China’s government has made it harder to move money overseas. It has said it would punish companies for investing in certain sectors. It has told firms to report all cross-border deals.
